summary: This document is a chain of emails from July 2019 regarding travel approval requests for FBI agents and an Assistant U.S. Attorney to conduct victim interviews in Florida and Los Angeles as part of the investigation into Jeffrey Epstein (case 2018R01618). The emails detail logistical planning, approvals, and references to prior travel for the same case.

connections.description: Work together as part of the investigative team (AUSA and FBI agents) traveling for victim interviews in the Epstein case.

events.title: Planned travel for victim interviews in Palm Beach
events.description: Travel planned for some combination of the investigative team (S, M, and possibly others) to conduct victim interviews in Palm Beach, Florida, from Thursday through Sunday, including a request to reserve a hotel conference room.

events.title: Approval for prior travel request
events.description: Travel approval was granted on June 12, 2019, for an earlier trip related to the Epstein investigation.

events.title: Travel request for Los Angeles victim interview
events.description: Request for permission to travel to Los Angeles for a victim interview, tentatively from Wednesday to Friday.

events.title: Travel approval for West Palm Beach meetings
events.description: Approval granted for travel to West Palm Beach, Florida, for approximately three days for meetings and interviews with victims.

events.title: Initial travel request for Epstein investigation
events.description: Initial request by S (AUSA) and another individual for travel to West Palm Beach and/or Fort Lauderdale, Florida, for two days of meetings and interviews related to United States v. Epstein.

keyFacts: The document shows active FBI and AUSA investigation into Jeffrey Epstein (case 2018R01618) in July 2019, focusing on victim interviews in multiple locations.
Travel requests indicate the investigative team planned trips to Florida (Palm Beach, West Palm Beach, Fort Lauderdale) and Los Angeles for victim interviews.
Emails reference standard government travel procedures and approvals within the DOJ, including the use of E2 Solutions for authorization.
The case is formally referenced as 'United States v. Epstein, 2018R01618, an investigation relating to enticement of minors for sexual activity'.
The correspondence reveals coordination between an Assistant U.S. Attorney (S) and FBI agents (including M) as part of the investigative team.
